instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What can tabular data be used for and what does it usually eliminate?
output: Tabular data may be used to specify performance and will usually eliminate the need for dual performance curves.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Determining Cooling Coil Sensible Capacity -> text
input: What controls the zone terminal unit's cooling coil?
output: The zone terminal unit's cooling coil is controlled by a zone thermostat.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Determining Cooling Coil Sensible Capacity -> text
input: How is the cooling coil's sensible capacity defined?
output: The cooling coil's sensible capacity is defined as the cooling coil's total capacity multiplied by the coil's sensible heat ratio (SHR) at the current operation conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Determining Cooling Coil Sensible Capacity -> text
input: Why must an iterative solution technique be used to determine the coil's sensible capacity?
output: Because the SHR of the variable refrigerant flow cooling coil changes as the inlet air wet-bulb temperature and the operating part-load ratio change.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Determining Cooling Coil Sensible Capacity -> text
input: When is the target solution for the coil's sensible capacity found?
output: When the sensible capacity of the zone cooling coil equals the zone sensible cooling load if sufficient capacity is available.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Determining Cooling Coil Sensible Capacity -> text
input: When does the iterative solution converge?
output: When the difference (error) between the zone sensible cooling load and the terminal unit sensible cooling capacity is within tolerance (0.001) or the terminal unit has insufficient capacity.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Determining Cooling Coil Sensible Capacity -> text
input: Where can further details on the VRF cooling coil model be found?
output: Refer to the description of the VRF cooling coil model.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Determining Cooling Coil Sensible Capacity -> equation
input: What is the equation for the zone terminal unit's total cooling capacity?
output: \\( \\dotQ_coil(i)coolingtotal = \\dotQ_coil(i)coolingrated \\left( CAPFT_coilcooling \\right) \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Determining Cooling Coil Sensible Capacity -> equation
input: What is the equation for the part-load ratio?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Determining Cooling Coil Sensible Capacity -> equation
input: What is the iterative loop equation for the cooling coil sensible capacity?
output: \\( \\beginarrayl Iteration~Loop~(PLR_i) \\\\ ~~~~SHR_PLR = f \\left( T_wbiPLR_i\\dotm_i \\right) \\\\ ~~~~\\dotQ_coil(i)coolingsensible = \\dotQ_coil(i)coolingtotal \\left( SHR_PLR \\right) \\left( PLR_i \\right) \\\\ ~~~~Error = \\left( \\dotQ_zone(i) - \\dotQ_coil(i)coolingsensible \\right) / \\dotQ_zone(i) \\\\ End~Iteration~Loop \\endarray \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Determining Cooling Coil Sensible Capacity -> text
input: What does \\( \\dotQ_coil(i)coolingtotal \\) represent?
output: It is the zone terminal unit total (sensible + latent) cooling capacity (W) report variable \Zone VRF Air Terminal Total Cooling Rate\.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Determining Cooling Coil Sensible Capacity -> text
input: What does \\( \\dotQ_coil(i)coolingsensible \\) represent?
output: It is the zone terminal unit sensible cooling capacity (W) report variable \Zone VRF Air Terminal Sensible Cooling Rate\.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Determining Cooling Coil Sensible Capacity -> text
input: What does \\( PLR_i \\) represent?
output: It is the cooling coil sensible part-load ratio in zone \\emphi.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Determining Cooling Coil Sensible Capacity -> text
input: What does \\( SHR_PLR \\) represent?
output: It is the cooling coil sensible heat ratio (function of PLR inlet air wet-bulb temperature and cooling coil inlet air mass flow rate).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Determining Cooling Coil Sensible Capacity -> text
input: What does \\( \\dotm_i \\) represent?
output: It is the cooling coil inlet air mass flow rate (m\\(^3\\)/s).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Determining Cooling Coil Sensible Capacity -> text
input: What does the terminal unit total cooling capacity include?
output: The impacts of fan heat and any outdoor air provided to the zone.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is the target solution for determining the coil's sensible capacity?
output: The target solution is found when the sensible capacity of the zone cooling coil equals the zone sensible cooling load (if sufficient capacity is available).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: When does the iterative solution for the coil's sensible capacity converge?
output: The iterative solution converges when the difference (error) between the zone sensible cooling load and the terminal unit sensible cooling capacity is within tolerance (0.001) or the terminal unit has insufficient capacity to meet the zone sensible cooling load.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: Where can further details on the VRF cooling coil model be found?
output: Refer to the description of the VRF cooling coil model for further details (ref: Variable Refrigerant Flow Cooling Coil).

input: What is the equation for the total cooling capacity of the coil?
output: \\( \\dotQ_coil(i)coolingtotal = \\dotQ_coil(i)coolingrated \\left( CAPFT_coilcooling \\right) \\)

input: What is the equation for the part-load ratio?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> equation
input: What is the iteration loop equation for determining sensible cooling capacity?
output: \\( \\beginarrayl Iteration~Loop~(PLR_i) \\\\ ~~~~SHR_PLR = f \\left( T_wbiPLR_i\\dotm_i \\right) \\\\ ~~~~\\dotQ_coil(i)coolingsensible = \\dotQ_coil(i)coolingtotal \\left( SHR_PLR \\right) \\left( PLR_i \\right) \\\\ ~~~~Error = \\left( \\dotQ_zone(i) - \\dotQ_coil(i)coolingsensible \\right) / \\dotQ_zone(i) \\\\ End~Iteration~Loop \\endarray \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What does \\(\\dotQ_coil(i)coolingtotal\\) represent?
output: \\(\\dotQ_coil(i)coolingtotal\\) is the zone terminal unit total (sensible + latent) cooling capacity (W) report variable 'Zone VRF Air Terminal Total Cooling Rate'.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What does \\(\\dotQ_coil(i)coolingsensible\\) represent?
output: \\(\\dotQ_coil(i)coolingsensible\\) is the zone terminal unit sensible cooling capacity (W) report variable 'Zone VRF Air Terminal Sensible Cooling Rate'.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is \\(PLR_i\\)?
output: \\(PLR_i\\) is the cooling coil sensible part-load ratio in zone \\emphi.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What does \\(SHR_PLR\\) stand for?
output: \\(SHR_PLR\\) is the cooling coil sensible heat ratio (function of PLR inlet air wet-bulb temperature and cooling coil inlet air mass flow rate).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is \\(\\dotm_i\\)?
output: \\(\\dotm_i\\) is the cooling coil inlet air mass flow rate (m\\(^3\\)/s).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: How is the total terminal unit cooling requirement calculated?
output: The terminal unit total cooling (sensible + latent) capacity is then summed to provide the total terminal unit cooling requirement.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What factors impact the cooling coil's capacity?
output: The cooling coil's capacity includes the impacts of fan heat and any outdoor air provided to the zone.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for the total terminal unit cooling requirement?
output: \\( \\dotQ_coolingTerminalUnits = \\sum\\limits_1^i \\left( \\dotQ_coil(i)coolingtotal \\right) \\left( PLR(i) \\right) \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What does \\(\\dotQ_cooling\\TerminalUnits\\) represent?
output: \\(\\dotQ_cooling\\TerminalUnits\\) is the total terminal unit cooling requirement (sensible + latent) in all zones (W).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is the purpose of the piping correction factor?
output: The piping correction factor is used to adjust the total zone cooling requirement to account for piping losses in the air conditioner's refrigeration piping system.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Cooling Piping Correction Factor in cooling mode -> text
input: How is the cooling piping correction factor calculated?
output: The cooling piping correction factor is calculated using either one or two independent variables. Both the equivalent piping length and the combination ratio are used together to determine piping losses or the equivalent piping length itself is used.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Cooling Piping Correction Factor in cooling mode -> text
input: What additional factor is considered in the cooling piping correction factor calculation?
output: The vertical height specified by the user is also added to the result calculated by either method.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Cooling Piping Correction Factor in cooling mode -> text
input: What type of equation is used if a single independent variable is used for the cooling piping correction factor?
output: If a single independent variable is used a linear quadratic or cubic equation is used to determine the equivalent length correction factor.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Cooling Piping Correction Factor in cooling mode -> text
input: What type of equation is used if two independent variables are used for the cooling piping correction factor?
output: If two independent variables are used a biquadratic equation is used to determine the equivalent length correction factor.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Cooling Piping Correction Factor in cooling mode -> text
input: How does the program choose the correct equation for the cooling piping correction factor?
output: The program will automatically use the correct equation based on the performance curve type.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Cooling Piping Correction Factor in cooling mode -> text
input: What adjusts the piping correction factor based on height difference?
output: A single coefficient adjusts the piping correction factor based on the difference in height from the highest to lowest terminal unit.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Cooling Piping Correction Factor in cooling mode -> text
input: What are coefficients a-d (e) used for?
output: Coefficients a-d (e) are inputs in the piping correction factor for length in cooling mode performance curve object.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Cooling Piping Correction Factor in cooling mode -> text
input: What is coefficient f used for?
output: Coefficient f is a direct input to the VRF model as the piping correction factor for height in cooling mode coefficient.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Cooling Piping Correction Factor in cooling mode -> text
input: What is the equivalent piping length in cooling mode?
output: The equivalent piping length in cooling mode (P\\(_EQcooling\\)) is also a direct input in the VRF model.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Cooling Piping Correction Factor in cooling mode -> text
input: How is the cooling combination ratio calculated?
output: The cooling combination ratio (CR\\(_cooling\\)) is automatically calculated by the program.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Cooling Piping Correction Factor in cooling mode -> text
input: How is the vertical height defined?
output: The vertical height is the difference between the highest and lowest terminal unit (e.g. 12 m higher than condenser – 3 m lower than condenser = 9 m height).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for the total terminal unit cooling requirement?
output: \\(\\dotQ_coolingTerminalUnits = \\sum\\limits_1^i \\left( \\dotQ_coil(i)coolingtotal \\right) \\left( PLR(i) \\right)\\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text

output: It is the total terminal unit cooling requirement (sensible + latent) in all zones (W).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> equation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for the piping correction factor in cooling mode with one independent variable?
output: \\(P_correctioncooling = a + b \\left( P_EQcooling \\right) + c \\left( P_EQcooling \\right)^2 + d \\left( P_EQcooling \\right)^3 + f \\left( P_H \\right)\\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> equation

output: \\(P_correction\\cooling = a + b \\left( P_EQcooling \\right) + c \\left( P_EQcooling \\right)^2 + d \\left( CR_cooling \\right) + e \\left( CR_cooling \\right)^2 + f \\left( P_EQcooling \\right) \\left( CR_cooling \\right) + g \\left( P_H \\right)\\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: How is the total demand on the heat pump condenser calculated?
output: The total demand is calculated as the quotient of the total terminal unit cooling capacity and the cooling piping correction factor.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: Are the piping losses variable during the simulation?
output: No the piping losses are fixed throughout the simulation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for the heat pump's total available cooling capacity (\\dotQ_HPcoolingtotal)?
output: \\dotQ_HPcoolingtotal = \\dotQ_coolingtotalrated \\left( CAPFT_HPcooling \\right) \\left( CR_coolingcorrection \\right)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What does \\dotQ_coolingtotal represent?
output: \\dotQ_coolingtotal is the total heat pump condenser cooling load (W).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What does \\dotQ_HPcoolingtotal represent?
output: \\dotQ_HPcoolingtotal is the heat pump total available cooling capacity (W).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat-Recovery-Cooling-Capacity-Modifier -> text
input: How does the heat pump's available cooling capacity differ in heat recovery mode?
output: It is typically different than the available capacity when operating in cooling only mode.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat-Recovery-Cooling-Capacity-Modifier -> text
input: What is the purpose of the heat recovery cooling capacity modifier?
output: This modifier is used to adjust the available cooling capacity using a fraction when heat recovery is active.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat-Recovery-Cooling-Capacity-Modifier -> text
input: How is the fraction for the heat recovery cooling capacity modifier determined?
output: It is based on a bi-quadratic equation with weighted average indoor temperature and outdoor temperatures as the independent terms.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat-Recovery-Cooling-Capacity-Modifier -> equation
input: What is the equation for the heat recovery cooling capacity modifier (HRCapMod_HPcooling)?
output: HRCapMod_HPcooling = a + b \\left( T_ent \\right) + c \\left( T_ent \\right)^2 + d \\left( T_cond \\right) + e \\left( T_cond \\right)^2 + f \\left( T_ent \\right) \\left( T_cond \\right)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat-Recovery-Cooling-Capacity-Modifier -> text
input: How can the equation for the heat recovery cooling capacity modifier be used?
output: It can provide a constant fractional difference for available cooling capacity in heat recovery mode or a fractional term that varies with indoor and outdoor conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat-Recovery-Cooling-Capacity-Modifier -> text
input: What is recommended due to limited performance data for the heat recovery cooling capacity modifier?
output: It is recommended that only the constant (a) term be used at this time.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: How is the condenser cooling capacity calculated?
output: The condenser cooling capacity is calculated as the quotient of the total terminal unit cooling capacity and the cooling piping correction factor.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: Are the piping losses variable throughout the simulation?
output: No the piping losses are fixed throughout the simulation and are not based on which terminal units are requesting refrigerant.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for the total cooling load of the heat pump condenser?
output: \\( \\dotQ_coolingtotal = \\frac\\dotQ_coolingTerminalUnitsP_correctioncooling \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: How is the heat pump's total available cooling capacity calculated?
output: The heat pump's total available cooling capacity is calculated using the rated total cooling capacity a capacity factor for cooling and a correction factor for cooling.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for the heat pump's total available cooling capacity?
output: \\( \\dotQ_HPcoolingtotal = \\dotQ_coolingtotalrated \\left( CAPFT_HPcooling \\right) \\left( CR_coolingcorrection \\right) \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What does \\(\\dotQ_coolingtotal\\) represent?
output: \\(\\dotQ_coolingtotal\\) represents the total heat pump condenser cooling load (W).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What does \\(\\dotQ_HPcoolingtotal\\) represent?
output: \\(\\dotQ_HPcoolingtotal\\) represents the heat pump total available cooling capacity (W).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat-Recovery-Cooling-Capacity-Modifier -> text
input: How is the heat pump's available cooling capacity different in heat recovery mode?
output: In heat recovery mode the heat pump's available cooling capacity is typically different than in cooling only mode and a modifier is used to adjust the available cooling capacity using a fraction.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat-Recovery-Cooling-Capacity-Modifier -> text
input: What is the basis for the fraction used to adjust cooling capacity in heat recovery mode?
output: The fraction is based on a bi-quadratic equation with weighted average indoor temperature and outdoor temperatures as the independent terms.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat-Recovery-Cooling-Capacity-Modifier -> equation
input: What is the equation for the heat recovery cooling capacity modifier?
output: \\( HRCapMod_HPcooling = a + b \\left( T_ent \\right) + c \\left( T_ent \\right)^2 + d \\left( T_cond \\right) + e \\left( T_cond \\right)^2 + f \\left( T_ent \\right) \\left( T_cond \\right) \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat-Recovery-Cooling-Capacity-Modifier -> text
input: How can the equation for the heat recovery cooling capacity modifier be used?
output: The equation can provide a constant fractional difference for available cooling capacity in heat recovery mode or a fractional term that varies with indoor and outdoor conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat-Recovery-Cooling-Capacity-Modifier -> text
input: What is recommended for the use of the coefficients in the heat recovery cooling capacity modifier equation?
output: It is recommended that only the constant (a) term be used due to limited performance data.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat-Recovery-Cooling-Capacity-Modifier -> text
input: What happens to the fraction when the VRF system is not operating in heat recovery mode?
output: The fraction is set to 1 when the VRF system is not operating in heat recovery mode.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat-Recovery-Cooling-Capacity-Modifier -> equation
input: What is the equation for the available cooling capacity in heat recovery mode?
output: \\( \\dotQ_HRcoolingtotal = \\dotQ_HPcoolingtotal \\left( HRCapMod_HPcooling \\right) \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat-Recovery-Cooling-Capacity-Modifier -> text
input: What does \\(\\dotQ_HRcoolingtotal\\) represent?
output: \\(\\dotQ_HRcoolingtotal\\) represents the heat recovery total available cooling capacity (W).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat-Recovery-Cooling-Capacity-Modifier -> text
input: What are the available cooling capacity and cooling energy fractions used to model heat recovery mode?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What happens when the heat pump changes operating modes?
output: When the heat pump changes operating modes there is a time delay and a period where the available cooling capacity is well below the steady-state capacity.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What curve is used to model the transition period?
output: An exponential decay curve is used to model the transition period.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: At the start of the transition period how much of the steady-state capacity in heat recovery mode is available?
output: Only a fraction (k_cool) of the steady-state capacity in heat recovery mode is available at the start of the transition period.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: How long does it take to recover the remaining capacity during the transition period?
output: The remaining capacity is recovered over a period of 5 time constants (t_c).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> equation
input: What equation is used to model the cooling capacity and condenser power curves during the transition period?
output: The equation is: \(\dotQ_HRavailcooling = k_cool \left( \dotQ_HRcoolingtotal \right) + \left( 1 - k_cool \right) \left( \dotQ_HRcoolingtotal \right) \left( 1 - e^\left( -t / \tau_c \right) \right)\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is the fraction of steady-state capacity at the beginning of heat recovery mode?
output: The fraction of steady-state capacity at the beginning of heat recovery mode is represented by \(k_cool\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is the time constant to reach steady-state operation?
output: The time constant to reach steady-state operation is \(t_c\) where 5 time constants equals 99% of steady-state capacity.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is \(\dotQ_HRavailcooling\)?
output: \(\dotQ_HRavailcooling\) is the available cooling capacity in heat recovery mode (W).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is the multiplier used during the transition period from cooling mode to heat recovery mode?
output: The multiplier is \(\left( 1 - e^\left( -t / t_ccool \right) \right)\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> equation
input: How is the operating part-load ratio of the VRF system calculated?
output: The operating part-load ratio (PLR) is calculated as: \(PLR = \frac\dotQ_coolingtotal\dotQ_HRavailcooling\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What happens to \(\dotQ_HRavailcooling\) when heat recovery mode is not active?
output: \(\dotQ_HRavailcooling\) is equivalent to \(\dotQ_HRcoolingtotal\) when heat recovery mode is not active.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What must be greater than or equal to the total cooling capacity requested by the zone terminal units?
output: The heat pump total available cooling capacity must be greater than or equal to the total cooling capacity requested by the zone terminal units.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What happens when the total operating capacity of all terminal units exceeds the available operating capacity of the heat pump condenser?
output: One or more of the terminal unit's operating capacity must be reduced to match the sum of the indoor terminal unit demand request plus piping losses with the total available cooling capacity of the outdoor condenser.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is the part-load ratio of the heat pump condenser when the total operating capacity matches the available capacity?
output: The part-load ratio of the heat pump condenser will be equal to 1.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is used to replicate both the cooling capacity and condenser power curves in the previous figure?
output: The following equation is used to replicate both the cooling capacity and condenser power curves in the previous figure.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for available cooling capacity in heat recovery mode?
output: \\( \\dotQ_HRavailcooling = k_cool \\left( \\dotQ_HRcoolingtotal \\right) + \\left( 1 - k_cool \\right) \\left( \\dotQ_HRcoolingtotal \\right) \\left( 1 - e^\\left( -t / \\tau_c \\right) \\right) \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What does \\(k_cool\\) represent in the equation?
output: \\(k_cool\\) is the fraction of steady-state capacity at the beginning of heat recovery mode.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is \\(t_c\\) in the context of the equation?
output: \\(t_c\\) is the time constant to reach steady-state operation with 5 time constants equaling 99% of steady-state capacity (hr).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is \\(Q_HRavailcooling\\)?
output: \\(Q_HRavailcooling\\) is the available cooling capacity in heat recovery mode (W).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What does the multiplier \\(\\left( 1 - e^\\left( -t / t_ccool \\right) \\right)\\) represent?
output: The multiplier \\(\\left( 1 - e^\\left( -t / t_ccool \\right) \\right)\\) is used during the transition period from cooling mode to heat recovery mode.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: How can the multiplier for the transition period be viewed?
output: The multiplier can be viewed using the report variable 'VRF Heat Pump Heat Recovery Status Change Multiplier' (ref: object Output:Variable).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for the operating part-load ratio of the VRF system?
output: \\( PLR = \\frac\\dotQ_coolingtotal\\dotQ_HRavailcooling \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What does PLR represent in the equation?
output: PLR is the heat pump part-load ratio report variable 'VRF Heat Pump Part Load Ratio'.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is \\(\\dotQ_HRavailcooling\\) equivalent to when heat recovery mode is not active?
output: For calculation purposes \\(\\dotQ_HRavailcooling\\) is equivalent to \\(\\dotQ_HRcoolingtotal\\) when heat recovery mode is not active.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What must the heat pump total available cooling capacity be greater than or equal to?
output: The heat pump total available cooling capacity must be greater than or equal to the total cooling capacity requested by the zone terminal units.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What happens when the total operating capacity of all terminal units is greater than the available operating capacity of the heat pump condenser?
output: One or more of the terminal unit's operating capacity must be reduced to the point where the sum of the indoor terminal unit demand request plus piping losses is equal to the total available cooling capacity of the outdoor condenser.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is the part-load ratio of the heat pump condenser when the total capacity equals the available capacity?
output: At this point the part-load ratio of the heat pump condenser will be equal to 1.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is used to restrict the cooling capacity of each indoor terminal unit?
output: A maximum terminal unit cooling capacity limit is used to restrict the cooling capacity of each indoor terminal unit.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is the capacity limit equivalent to?
output: The capacity limit is equivalent to a maximum allowed operating capacity for all zone terminal units.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What assumption is made about terminal units providing capacity?
output: The assumption is that no terminal unit can provide more capacity than can be delivered by the outdoor condenser.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> equation
input: What is the revised equation for terminal unit total cooling capacity calculation?
output: \\( \\dotQ_coil(i)\\cooling = \\sum\\limits_1^i MIN \\left( \\left( \\dotQ_coil(i)coolingtotal \\right) \\left( PLR(i) \\right)CoolingCapacityLimit \\right) \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is \\(CoolingCapacityLimit(CL_cooling)\\)?
output: \\(CoolingCapacityLimit(CL_cooling)\\) is the report variable (ref: Output:Variable) describing the 'VRF Heat Pump Maximum Capacity Cooling Rate' (W).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: When are terminal units more likely to be capacity limited?
output: Terminal units near their maximum capacity are more likely to be capacity limited than those operating well below their available capacity.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What happens when there is no terminal unit capacity limit?
output: When there is no terminal unit capacity limit this variable will report 1E+20 indicating that no limit exists.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What does the figure below demonstrate?
output: The figure demonstrates the application of the capacity limit factor for the case where all indoor terminal units are operating at different capacities.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: When is a solution reached regarding terminal unit cooling capacities?
output: A solution is reached when the sum of the indoor terminal unit's cooling capacities (accounting for piping losses) is equal to the heat pump condenser's available cooling capacity.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> figure in /UAStudy/EnergyPlus/doc/engineering-reference/media/

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is the cooling capacity limit used for?
output: The cooling capacity limit is equivalent to a maximum allowed operating capacity for all zone terminal units and is used to conserve energy between multiple indoor terminal units and a single outdoor condensing unit.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What assumption is made regarding terminal units and the outdoor condenser?
output: The assumption is that no terminal unit can provide more capacity than can be delivered by the outdoor condenser.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> equation
input: What is the revised equation for the terminal unit total cooling capacity calculation?
output: The revised equation is: \\( \\dotQ_coil(i)\\cooling = \\sum\\limits_1^i MIN \\left( \\left( \\dotQ_coil(i)coolingtotal \\right) \\left( PLR(i) \\right)CoolingCapacityLimit \\right) \\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What does the variable CoolingCapacityLimit represent?
output: CoolingCapacityLimit (CL_cooling) is the report variable describing the 'VRF Heat Pump Maximum Capacity Cooling Rate (W).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What happens when multiple terminal units are operating near their maximum capacity?
output: Terminal units near their maximum capacity are more likely to be capacity limited than those operating well below their available capacity.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is reported when there is no terminal unit capacity limit?
output: When there is no terminal unit capacity limit the variable will report 1E+20 indicating that no limit exists.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> figure
input: What does the figure demonstrate?
output: The figure demonstrates the application of the capacity limit factor for the case where all indoor terminal units are operating at different capacities.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is a solution in the context of terminal unit cooling capacities and heat pump condenser capacity?
output: A solution is reached when the sum of the indoor terminal unit's cooling capacities (accounting for piping losses) is equal to the heat pump condenser's available cooling capacity.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What happens when the heat pump's part-load ratio is less than 1?
output: When the heat pump's part-load ratio is less than 1 it is compared to the minimum heat pump part-load ratio and if it is less the heat pump will cycle on and off to meet the cooling load.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is used to account for startup losses of the compression system?
output: A correction factor is used to account for startup losses of the compression system.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is the cooling part-load fraction correlation?
output: The cooling part-load fraction correlation is a linear quadratic or cubic curve with the independent variable being cycling ratio (part-load ratio / minimum part-load ratio).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for CyclingRatioFrac?
output: The equation for CyclingRatioFrac is: \\( CyclingRatioFrac = a + b \\left( CyclingRatio \\right) + c \\left( CyclingRatio \\right)^2 + d \\left( CyclingRatio \\right)^3 \\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> equation
input: How is CyclingRatio defined?
output: CyclingRatio is defined as: \\( CyclingRatio = \\fracPLRPLR_min \\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What are a-c (d) in the context of the cycling ratio correlation curve equation?
output: a-c (d) are the coefficients for the quadratic (cubic) cycling ratio correlation curve equation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What should the cooling part-load ratio correlation be normalized to?
output: The cooling part-load ratio correlation should be normalized to a value of 1.0 when the cycling ratio equals 1.0.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is the rule for CyclingRatioFrac when CyclingRatio is between 0 and 1?
output: For cycling ratio values between 0 and 1 the rules are: \\(CyclingRatioFrac \\geq 0.7\\) and \\(CyclingRatioFrac \\geq CyclingRatio\\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What happens if CyclingRatioFrac is less than 0.7?
output: If CyclingRatioFrac is less than 0.7 a warning message is issued the program resets the CyclingRatioFrac value to 0.7 and the simulation proceeds.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: How is the runtime fraction of the heat pump defined?
output: The runtime fraction of the heat pump is defined as CyclingRatio/CyclingRatioFrac.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What happens if CyclingRatioFrac is less than CyclingRatio?
output: If CyclingRatioFrac is less than CyclingRatio a warning message is issued and the runtime fraction of the heat pump is limited to 1.0.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What happens if the heat pump's part-load ratio is less than the minimum heat pump part-load ratio?
output: The heat pump will cycle on and off to meet the cooling load.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is used to account for startup losses of the compression system?
output: A correction factor is used to account for startup losses of the compression system.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What type of curve is the cooling part-load fraction correlation?
output: The cooling part-load fraction correlation is a linear quadratic or cubic curve.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for CyclingRatioFrac?
output: CyclingRatioFrac = a + b (CyclingRatio) + c (CyclingRatio)^2 + d (CyclingRatio)^3

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> equation
input: How is CyclingRatio defined?
output: CyclingRatio = PLR / PLR_min

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What are a-c (d) in the cycling ratio correlation curve equation?
output: They are the coefficients for the quadratic (cubic) cycling ratio correlation curve equation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What should the cooling part-load ratio correlation be normalized to when the cycling ratio equals 1.0?
output: It should be normalized to a value of 1.0.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What happens if CyclingRatioFrac is less than 0.7?
output: A warning message is issued the program resets the CyclingRatioFrac value to 0.7 and the simulation proceeds.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: How is the runtime fraction of the heat pump defined?
output: The runtime fraction of the heat pump is defined as CyclingRatio/CyclingRatioFrac.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What happens if CyclingRatioFrac is less than CyclingRatio?
output: A warning message is issued and the runtime fraction of the heat pump is limited to 1.0.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for Heat Pump Runtime Fraction (HPRTF)?
output: Heat Pump Runtime Fraction (HPRTF) = CyclingRatio / CyclingRatioFrac

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What correlation may be substituted for VRF AC systems due to lack of cycling losses data?
output: A typical part-load fraction correlation for a conventional DX refrigeration system may be substituted.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> equation
input: What is the typical part-load fraction correlation for a conventional DX refrigeration system?
output: CyclingRatioFrac = 0.85 + 0.15(CyclingRatio)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What factors are used to correct for off-design performance?
output: Performance correction factors are used to correct for off-design performance.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is the cooling energy input ratio modifier function of low temperature?
output: It is a curve that can be applied as a single curve object or using dual performance curve objects.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation form for the cooling energy input ratio modifier function?
output: EIRFT_cooling = a + b (T_wbavg) + c (T_wbavg)^2 + d (T_c) + e (T_c)^2 + f (T_wbavg) (T_c)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is EIRFT_cooling?
output: EIRFT_cooling is the cooling energy input ratio modifier (function of temperature).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is the runtime fraction limit for the heat pump?
output: The runtime fraction of the heat pump is limited to 1.0.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for the Heat Pump Runtime Fraction (HPRTF)?
output: Heat~Pump~Runtime~Fraction~(HPRTF) = \\fracCyclingRatioCyclingRatioFrac

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: How can the heat pump runtime fraction be viewed?
output: The heat pump runtime fraction can be viewed using the report variable 'VRF Heat Pump Runtime Fraction (ref: Output:Variable).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What can be used as a substitute for cycling losses data of VRF AC systems?
output: A typical part-load fraction correlation for a conventional DX refrigeration system may be substituted.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for CyclingRatioFrac?
output: CyclingRatioFrac = 0.85 + 0.15(CyclingRatio)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: How is the electrical power consumed by the heat pump condenser calculated?
output: The electrical power is calculated based on the heat pump's rated electric power consumption actual operating conditions and the cycling ratio of the refrigeration system.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What are used to correct for off-design performance?
output: Performance correction factors are used to correct for off-design performance.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What does the cooling energy input ratio modifier function of low temperature describe?
output: It describes the application of a single or dual performance curve for water-cooled systems based on indoor air wet-bulb temperature and outdoor condenser entering water temperature.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation form for the cooling energy input ratio modifier function of temperature?
output: EIRFT_cooling = a + b \\left( T_wbavg \\right) + c \\left( T_wbavg \\right)^2 + d \\left( T_c \\right) + e \\left( T_c \\right)^2 + f \\left( T_wbavg \\right) \\left( T_c \\right)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is EIRFT_cooling?
output: EIRFT_cooling is the cooling energy input ratio modifier (function of temperature).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is the basis of the cooling energy input ratio calculation?
output: The cooling energy input ratio calculation is based on two EIR curves.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: When is the second curve for cooling energy input ratio used?
output: The second curve is used when the heat pump part-load ratio is greater than 1.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What happens when the part-load ratio curve for PLR>1 is not used?
output: When not used the energy use is assumed to be constant when PLR > 1.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for EIRFPLR_cooling when PLR \\leq 1?
output:
IF\left( PLR \leq 1 \right)THEN 
  ~~~~EIRFPLR_cooling = a + b \left( PLR \right) + c \left( PLR \right)^2 + d \left( PLR \right)^3 
  ELSE 
  ~~~~EIRFPLR_cooling = e + f \left( PLR \right) + g \left( PLR \right)^2 + h \left( PLR \right)^3

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is EIRFPLR_cooling?
output: EIRFPLR_cooling is the cooling energy input ratio correction factor (function of part-load ratio).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What are the coefficients a-d used for?
output: They are used for cooling energy input ratio correlation when part-load ratio \\(\\leq\\) 1.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What are the coefficients e-h used for?
output: They are used for cooling energy input ratio correlation when part-load ratio > 1.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> equation
input: How is the total power consumed by the heat pump condenser in cooling mode calculated?
output: P_\\mathrmCooling = \\left( \\frac\\dotQ_coolingtotalrated CAPFT_coolingCOP_coolingreference \\right) \\left( EIRFT_cooling \\right) \\left( EIRFPLR_cooling \\right) \\left( HPRTF \\right)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: How is the cooling COP calculated?
output: The cooling COP is calculated as the ratio of the outdoor unit cooling capacity divided by the total electric consumption rate of all components associated with the outdoor unit.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is typically 0 during cooling mode operation?
output: Defrost power is typically 0 during cooling mode operation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for COP_cooling?
output: COP_cooling = \\frac\\dotQ_coolingtotalP_\\mathrmCooling + P_CrankCaseHeater + P_EvapCoolerPump + P_defrost

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is COP_cooling?
output: COP_cooling is the operating coefficient of performance report variable 'VRF Heat Pump Cooling COP'.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is the cooling energy input ratio calculation based on?
output: The cooling energy input ratio calculation is based on 2 EIR curves.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: When is the first EIR curve used in the cooling energy input ratio calculation?
output: The first EIR curve is used when the heat pump part-load ratio is less than or equal to 1.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What describes the variation of cooling energy input ratio when the part-load ratio is greater than 1?
output: A second curve is used to describe the variation of cooling energy input ratio when the part-load ratio is greater than 1.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What happens to energy use when the part-load ratio curve for PLR>1 is not used?
output: When the part-load ratio curve for PLR>1 is not used the energy use is assumed to be constant when PLR > 1.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation used to calculate the cooling energy input ratio correction factor when PLR ≤ 1?
output: IF(PLR ≤ 1) THEN EIRFPLR_cooling = a + b (PLR) + c (PLR)^2 + d (PLR)^3 ELSE EIRFPLR_cooling = e + f (PLR) + g (PLR)^2 + h (PLR)^3

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is EIRFPLR_cooling?
output: EIRFPLR_cooling is the cooling energy input ratio correction factor (function of part-load ratio).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What are the coefficients a-d used for?
output: Coefficients a-d are used for cooling energy input ratio correlation when part-load ratio ≤ 1.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What are the coefficients e-h used for?
output: Coefficients e-h are used for cooling energy input ratio correlation when part-load ratio > 1.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: How is the total power consumed by the heat pump condenser in cooling mode calculated?
output: The total power consumed by the heat pump condenser in cooling mode is based on the user specified coefficient of performance (COP) and calculated using the formula: P_Cooling = (Q̇_coolingtotalrated CAPFT_cooling / COP_coolingreference) (EIRFT_cooling) (EIRFPLR_cooling) (HPRTF)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for calculating the total power consumed by the heat pump condenser in cooling mode?
output: P_Cooling = (Q̇_coolingtotalrated CAPFT_cooling / COP_coolingreference) (EIRFT_cooling) (EIRFPLR_cooling) (HPRTF)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: How is the cooling COP calculated?
output: The cooling COP is calculated as the ratio of the outdoor unit cooling capacity divided by the total electric consumption rate of all components associated with the outdoor unit.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is typically the value of defrost power during cooling mode operation?
output: Defrost power is typically 0 during cooling mode operation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for calculating the cooling COP?
output: COP_cooling = (Q̇_coolingtotal) / (P_Cooling + P_CrankCaseHeater + P_EvapCoolerPump + P_defrost)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is COP_cooling?
output: COP_cooling is the operating coefficient of performance report variable 'VRF Heat Pump Cooling COP'.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is P_Cooling?
output: P_Cooling is the operating electric consumption rate (W) report variable 'VRF Heat Pump Cooling Electric Power'.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is P_CrankcaseHeater?
output: P_CrankcaseHeater is the report variable for electric consumption rate of crankcase heater (W).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is P_EvapCoolerPump?
output: P_EvapCoolerPump is the report variable for electric consumption rate of evaporatively-cooled condenser water pump (W).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is P_defrost?
output: P_defrost is the report variable for average defrost power for the simulation time step (W).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What happens when operating in heat recovery mode?
output: When operating in heat recovery mode equations similar to those used for available cooling capacity are used to model heating electric consumption rate.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation used for modeling heating electric consumption rate in heat recovery mode?
output: HREIRMod_HPcooling = a + b (T_ent) + c (T_ent)^2 + d (T_cond) + e (T_cond)^2 + f (T_ent) (T_cond)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What does the equation for HREIRMod_HPcooling provide?
output: This equation can be used to provide a constant fractional difference for cooling electric consumption rate in heat recovery mode (i.e. only a is non-zero) or a fractional term that varies with indoor and outdoor conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is recommended with the limited performance data available for HREIRMod_HPcooling?
output: With very limited performance data available at this time it is recommended that only the constant (a) term be used at this time.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is the fraction set to when the VRF system is not operating in heat recovery mode?
output: When the VRF system is not operating in heat recovery mode this fraction is set to 1.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: How is the cooling electric consumption rate in heat recovery mode calculated?
output: The cooling electric consumption rate in heat recovery mode is calculated as P_Cooling HR = P_Cooling (HREIRMod_HPcooling).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for calculating the cooling electric consumption rate in heat recovery mode?
output: P_Cooling HR = P_Cooling (HREIRMod_HPcooling)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for calculating Power_HR?
output: Power_HR = k_EIRcool · P_Cooling HR + (1 - k_EIRcool) · P_Cooling HR · (1 - e^(-t / τ_cEIRcool))

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is k_EIRcool?
output: k_EIRcool is the fraction of steady-state cooling electric consumption rate at the beginning of heat recovery mode.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is τ_cEIRcool?
output: τ_cEIRcool is the time constant to reach steady-state operation with 5 time constants equaling 99% of steady-state capacity (hr).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is P_Cooling HR?
output: P_Cooling HR is the cooling electric consumption rate in heat recovery mode.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is $P_\\mathrmCooling$?
output: $P_\\mathrmCooling$ is the operating electric consumption rate (W) report variable ``VRF Heat Pump Cooling Electric Power.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is $P_CrankcaseHeater$?
output: $P_CrankcaseHeater$ is the report variable for electric consumption rate of crankcase heater (W).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is $P_EvapCoolerPump$?
output: $P_EvapCoolerPump$ is the report variable for electric consumption rate of evaporatively-cooled condenser water pump (W).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What is $P_defrost$?
output: $P_defrost$ is the report variable for average defrost power for the simulation time step (W).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> text
input: What happens when operating in heat recovery mode?
output: Equations similar to those used for available cooling capacity are used to model heating electric consumption rate.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Variable Refrigerant Flow Heat Pumps -> equation
input: What is the equation for $HREIRMod_HPcooling$?
